summary: An evil immortal swordsman (Mario Van Peebles) catches up to his sorcerer foe (Christopher Lambert) at a deserted New Jersey refinery.

reviews.content: We want it back and we want to see Christopher Lambert back in movies, please
We want it back and we want to see Christopher Lambert back in movies, please
Better than the II, these guys keep coming back eventhough always mentioned he is the last but at least enjoyable...

While Highlander (1986) was impressive in it's visual and bombastic and somewhat cheesy acting... this movie takes that to a whole new level. Awful and pretty much unwatchable, I managed to get through this and yeah, I know what the "Final Dimension" is... There should have been only one.
Well it is better than part 2 at least. The site messed it up though. Christopher Lambert is the star here. Not the television show star, Adrian Paul. He is in part 4 though.

It was interesting to see Mako play a wizard again(Conan the Barbarian/Destroyer) an immortal wizard and a mentor of Connor. People claim that this movie is a carbon copy of the original. I disagree. Yes it shares alot of similar plot points. But this movie builds on the Highlander universe. We see the use of magic more prominently displayed. Which to me builds up the race of immortals in the minds of the viewers. With the view point that each immortal is different with different skills, abilities and yes even magical powers. This to me mirrors how we see immortals in the Series. For me this movie was an expansion on the lore of the universe which I enjoyed.

A valiant effort to erase the lobotomy inducing H2 this straight to video, cheap imitation of the original is an awkwardly silly movie... could they not think of anything better than the villain being trapped in a cave for centuries?!? Beggars belief but not sure the writers have ever seen Highlander on this evidence.

A cash in on a popular name.
Bland action film without any real passion driving it. The first two were flawed yet innovative. This film struggles to find a few decent moments.
Completely separate storyline from one told in Highlander 2. Choose your sequel of preference I suppose.
Bad Cut and Paste of the first film. The one star is for Deborah Unger...

If you are sitting down to watch Highlander 3, I will assume you have already watched at least one of the previous films and know what to expect.

If for some reason this is your first Highlander film then. Welcome, pull up a chair, grab some popcorn, a tasty beverage and prepare yourself for a poor film, poorly written, poorly acted and full of effects that are far from special.

The best part of the film is the guy who has been trapped in a cave for 400 years but has no problem living in the world of 1994. Make a list of the things he does in 90's New York with no problem despite being from 16th century Japan.

This film might have been good if it was trimmed down and turned into an episode of the Highlander TV show but then again, maybe not.

Featured on Episode 58 of The Emerald Reprobates Podcast
The best Highlander sequel, but thats not saying much.
Least favorite highlander movie

Don't believe the synopsis for this film on flixster. This film isn't segments from the Adrian Paul Highlander tv show. And this version is not a direct to video release. I went to the theater to watch this film. 
This film stars Christopher Lambert as the Highlander and Mario Van People's as the villain. This movie takes place after the events in the first film, completely ignoring the events of the second film. This film fall's under the law of diminishing returns. Another disappointing sequel. It's more entertaining than Highlander 2, but so is getting 3 teeth pulled at once without pain killers. Poorly acted, crappy fx. Don't bother!
I can't believe I'm saying this, but I think I actually like the third movie more than the original - I certainly had a lot more fun watching it!
Why do they keep trying!? Shouldn't Highlander 2 have been enough of a deterrent toward attempting another movie!?

After the disaster of the second film, a third film was more-or-less welcomed. Unfortunately, it was just another poor sequel. The plot essentially is the first film all over again, all it does is put a new coat of paint on it. None of the actors really give the film life, even Christopher Lambert acts like he doesn't want to really be there. Oh yeah, Connor has a kid, so yeah. Mario Van Peebles is easily the worst character on screen. He plays a Kurgan wanna be. He's a magician and bad one at that. For all the fans of Mako Iwamatsu, he makes a role in this film but much like the rest of the acting, you'll be disappointed. The special effects are mediocre to acceptable. Overall the film is just a bore, it is better than the other sequels but that's not saying much. Stick with the first "Highlander" film and don't waste your time with the sequels, even this one.

This third episode of the franchise is probably the weakest. Through some unbelievable magic tricks of the scenario they send the story in a complete different direction trying to make everyone forget film number two. It's quite a cheesy film, the special effects look pretty cheap & the story doesn't make any sense to me.... that was the early 90's....whatever.
Lambert is as uncharismatic as ever, while Van Peebles is as frightening as a wrestler in mock angry mood, and just as ridiculous. was to b the final but it made $$$ so...
More garbage that has nothing to do with the brilliant original.  Really bad.
I liked this one beteer than #2 as it appeared to return to the original story line concept from the first movie.
Christopher Lambert has nailed the role as Duncan once again
This was another good addition to the Highlander saga!
Not a great film, but leagues ahead of Highlander 2. It's at least coherent, and gives Lambert another shot at playing Connor McLeod.
much improved against number 2

Highlander III: Final Dimension doesn't punch it's fans in the face like Highlander II: The Quickening did, but it doesn't entertain them either and squanders a large budget on poor special effects and turns a potentially good premise into a boring unstructured film.
The key problem with Highlander II: The Quickening was that it tried way too hard, and then the problem with Highlander III: Final Dimension was that it didn't try at all.t just became a rehash of the first one with poorly edited fight scenes and little fun to be had. And despite a sizeable budget, it just looked so cheap. Also, Highlander III: Final Dimension involves a complicated background story to Connor MacLeod about his exploits in France, and this actually has no relevance to the story and does nothing for any character, so it's just a pointless time-filling aspect of the film's running time.
And another problem is that Highlander III: Final Dimension is devoid of the fun of the original Highlander, because it just takes itself too seriously and doesn't embody the tone that made the original so awesome, and it attempts to re-establish that towards the end of the film but by that point the damage has been done.
The only good thing about Highlander III: Final Dimension is that since it ignores the plot of Highlander II: The Quickening, it's safe to assume that we can all pretend it never existed. It does also feature some good cinematography moments and has an ok musical score. 
But nevertheless, Highlander III: Final Dimension was unimpressive and only really drew any strength from Christopher Lambert's performance which was weaker than before, but still somewhat good for the character.
Mario Van Peebles however decides to poorly overemphasize every word with a cheap Batman voice.
So Highlander III: Final Dimension is a poor looking film, but is milestones ahead of it's horrible predecessor and is more likely to provide enjoyment for fans of the franchise, yet still it's unlikely to provide much.
Better than the second one, at least...
Even I hate this movie and I really love Highlander.
The worst of all the sequels, simply because they were TRYING to make it better than the second.
not the best,,,,,,,,,but good
There should have been only one!
The third chapter in the Highlander trilogy is just more proof that there should have been only one.
It was ok in doses, felt repetitive after the first two predessesors.
there should have been only one
Why they made this I'll never know.

Oh, goddammit! I love another Highlander sequel! I can't believe this! I liked Highlander II (Renegade Version), and now I also enjoy the widely hated third film. This film ignores the events of the second film, but it is no less an extremely goofy and wildly over-the-top action film that embraces its lunacy to the fullest degree since the story is cheesy, the acting is even cheesier (I love Mario Van Peebles's performance as Kane), and the action is intense and thrilling. I had an absolute blast watching this film and will forever cherish it because of the way it is. There are good reasons why most people hate this film, but this might appeal to fans of cheesy action films. I love this corny mess of a film.

Does its best to erase the stain of the second film by completely ignoring the immortals are aliens explanation.  Very similar story to the original.  Lambert is good here but Van Peebles is laughably over the top.
No...why...just stop.

How this has the same rating as the Last Airbender I don't know. Honestly, a good sequel that continues things nicely from the first, without going out on a massive retcon like 2 did. Peebles plays a similar over the top Kurgan-esque bad guy, hell this movie copies some the same scenes. Oh and the opening reminded me of Conan the Barbarian or maybe its just the presence of Mako.

To be quite fair, I think this was a film with a fantastic idea. Then the studio had to get involved. What was left was a terrible script full of one dimensional characters.
Thankfully pretending that Part 2 didn't exist, Connor MacLeod, after the death of Ramirez in the original and the loss of Heather made a pilgrimage to Japan in search of Makano the Sorcerer. After Makano's death at the hands of the barbarian Kane, the villain is trapped for 400 years by a cave in. Fast forward to the 1990's where an archeological dig unearths them and the hunt for MacLeod is on.
With Deborah Unger and Mario Van Peeples it's a well cast Highlander film, has an inspired montage in Scotland but the execution and script just are too glaring a problem
love highlander but not this movie!!!

Wow, so this is another of those part 3 movies that says "we acknowledge that the second movie was a complete steaming pile so just pretend it never happened." And so it goes that this 3rd part actually is to take up just a few years after the original and Mccleod has to fight a long lost immortal who was buried in a mountain for 400 years. It really is irritating to me how they totally screwed up the sequels and in my opinion they should have just stuck with the original 1st Highlander and left it at that. This one was definitely better than the 2nd movie, but is the same formula as #1 and pales in comparison. Watch it if you are a big fan and try not to be too disappointed.

He's the Shang Tsung of Highlander and he even sounds like him from The Journey Begins. It's as offensive as Highlander II but still not very good. I haven't finished the movie yet, but this film just had the most hilarious product placement I've ever seen: Mountain Dew cans focusing energy during MacLeod's first quickening. 

Edit: Ok. I finished watching this and it actually wasn't half bad (as far as "Highlander" sequels go.) Obviously they were copying everything about the first movie, but it was far better than trying to completely change everything like they did with the first sequel. Plus, I think Christopher Lambert and Deborah Kara Unger had some good chemistry and the flashback scenes were interesting. Also, the element of sorcery was something new that could've been fun, but they didn't really do that much with it. Also, what was up with that ripoff of Motley Crue's "Dr. Feelgood" playing during the final fight?
The real sequel to Highlander is very entertaining and very well made, acted, directed and written. Still a little goofy because this series should have been a one piece

Better storyline than the second film. The bad guy was a bit too corny though. As in the first film they tried too hard to make him "bad". It can be much more effective to make the "bad guys" more subtly so. In my opinion anyway. The storyline basically ignores the second film and this again confuses the Highlander History. The film is worth watching but it is a shame that they felt the need to make sequels.

Coming off the mess that was "The Quickening," it was necessary to re-establish the core tenets of "Highlander" mythology. Unfortunately, this meant making a film that is, literally, a beat-for-beat copy of the 1986 original (and steals the rest of its story rhythms from "The Terminator"). Sure, the immortal lightning juju looks better now but everything else is a retread; if Mario Van Peebles was white and a foot taller, you could swear you were watching the first film. That's not to say this is a terrible approach--"Highlander" has always combined rad story elements with slapdash execution--but do we really need a B-movie version of what was already a B-movie in the first place?

Ultimately, you could call this "Highlander: With More Breasts," as it is also a charming artifact of the heydey of Bob Weinstein's neo-cheapie Dimension Films imprint.
Laughable at best, a complete mockery of the original.
So crappy, they made another one after inviting us all to ignore this one.
I thought it couldn't get any worse after the 2nd movie but it did. Steer clear of this mess.

bringing the series back from the terrible number two wouldn't be an easy task. my main problem with this film is that it doesn't continue on from anything from the second or the first. the only thing that does save the film is the action scenes and the style of the film. i found it had the style of the first film and for that i actually found some redeeming qualities. the bad side is the acting was bad and the story didn't really work. one of the weirdest series ever made

This is one of the better films from the Highlander collection and is far and away better than Highlander II: Renegade Version. It must be stated that the villain in this movie is better than both the Kurgan and General Katana. 

There is one important explanation as to the superiority of this feature over the others. This explanation is that the budget for this film is much greater than the budget for the others and is an example that big budget films are better (even though this is not at all true). 

The only problem with this film is the absence of Sean Connery as the teacher of our immortal hero.
At least it wasn't as bad as Highlander 2: "Immmorrrtaaalllsss in Sppppaaaaaaaaaaaaace"

Another chance to scream and shout "There Can Be Only ONE!" this time the highlander's up agains't an illusionist, whilst remembering what happened in Scotland all those years ago.

Eight years after the events of "Highlander", Connor MacLeod is travelling the world, but a foe he thought was dead returns to threaten his life.

This film is set back in the 'real world' eight years after the events of the first movie, and therefore totally wipes out all aspects of the second film.  This is not a good thing, as all the explanations used are totally ignored, and we are left with a complete WTF situation!!!  The idea of another immortal stuck in a cave just does not make any sense, as if that was the case Connor was never 'the one' and would have never won The Prize!!!!  Whether Connor was actually mortal or not is not even mentioned, and he just picks up his sword and starts lopping heads off as if no time had passed.  Christopher Lambert lack of acting abilities really shows here, as all he is doing is reguritating lines and facial expressions from the previous two outings.  Mario Van Peebles role as Kane is nothing more than a watered down version of Clancy Brown's wise-cracking Kurgan, and should learn that just growling your dialogue does not make for a good villain.  All-in-all, a downward turn for a good franchise.
one of my favorites in the series. i really like this one.

This pile of sucky suck suck fails the 25 minute test. Highlander 3 is evidence for the prosecution that nobody takes this franchise seriously enough to give it any sense of continuity.

Making a worse sequel than Highlander 2 was always going to be a challenge and although they do try very hard here to indeed achieve this nirvana of cinematic assness, it just falls short and ends up being mostly dull.

The film starts off pretty much exactly like Conan The Barbarian: bad guys on horses with silly helmets burning down a village, Mako, montages...literally all that's missing is Basil Poledouris's score. Then the nonsense inevitably begins as a statue inexplicably turns its head and opens its eyes, we cut to the present then back to 18th century France for some reason, we're given an odd, super long gratuitous sex scene and the list goes on.

That said, the film at the very least acknowledges the shortcomings of its predecessor as it doesn't even attempt to fix anything and just never mentions it. We are shown bits from the first film so we can only assume either the action is taking place in between 1 and 2 or they're just pretending like The Quickening never happened. Either way: that's fine by me. As long as we're on Earth...

Highlander: The Apology

Then again maybe not. Yes, it is an improvement over Highlander 2, but only slightly. Really, anything would have been an improvement. Basically the movie just ignores the second one and attempts to become the true sequel. I say attempts because it sucks, and to me it will never be a sequel.

The opening of the movie is a complete rip-off of Conan The Barbarian that it makes Terminators cry. It even has Mako in the film. 

Connor is trainig with Mako when Kane shows up. Mako has the ability to create illusions, giving him an edge over other Immortals. This doesn't stop Kane from taking his head as the cave collapses. Flash to present day and Connor hasn't won the Prize (though he thinks he has). Kane finally gets released fro munderground, and speaks perfect English. It's all pretty weak but hey, at least we don't have any aliens. OH GOD HIGHLANDER 2 FLASHBACK!

The worst problem about the movie is that it could have been better. It certainly couldn't have been worse. They just chose to copy the script from the first movie and remove all the cool aspects. I mean the illusion thing could have been a cool anomaly within the Immortals and the story could have been interesting but they put 0 work into it. At least Highlander 2 might be good if you were on acid. At least they put somethin into it that was different (even though it was the worst ideas ever). Highlander: The Final Dimension is still better though.

The film ends with a battle in an old factory (where action films go to die), and on a side note, I think Connor needs to thank the makers of pipes. You'd understand if you had seen......OH GOD HIGHLANDER 2 FLASHBACK!

Connor also has an adopted son in the movie who is kind of annoying. Of course there is also a love intrest because Scotsmen are total players! Apparently she is supposed to be a lot like a love that Conner once had...lame! Who cares anyway? Love intrests are usually just standard anyway.

Kane is kind of fun to watch because the performance is just so over the top. I mean he must have set a record for saying "There can be only one" in a film. His voice sounds like he moonlights as Dr. Claw, but I digress.

The Final Dimension? Yeah right. I think the series needs a real boost. Not a remake, just a good god damn movie. Fans deserve it, I can think of few other fanbases who have had to put up with this crap.
Gag-inducing, though not actually as awful as Highlander II.

  Conner MacLeod, an immortal Highlander currently living in 1994 New York City, must come face to face with his age-old and evil enemy, Highlander Kane, when Kane becomes freed from an archeological...  Conner MacLeod, an immortal Highlander currently living in 1994 New York City, must come face to face with his age-old and evil enemy, Highlander Kane, when Kane becomes freed from an archeological dig in Japan. In the 16th century, a similar battle took place, only for MacLeod to emerge victor and Kane to remain entrapped for five centuries within collapsed temple walls. Now, Kane is out for MacLeod's blood, and uses every superpower to destroy any future for MacLeod.

*SPOILER ALERT!* Again same old plot. Evil immortal, Good Mr. Highlander getting help from his friends to be powerful enough to save the human race. This one takes place between movies 1 and 2.  The villain is the most likable yet. Still annoying to his victims, but not so much to the audience. He even manages to keep his tongue in his mouth most of the time.  The beginning of the movie confuses me. Apparently the villain was just burried in a cave in.  Don't know why Conner got the quickening since he wasn't the last one.  Anyway the big uniqueness in this movie is that the villain had killed an immortal who was a sorceress, so there's tons of magic in this one.  As for the title, it seems incredibly stupid. I don't see at all where 'final dimension' comes in. I guess the only new information revealed in this movie is that if you do try to kill someone on holy ground, windows will shatter and scare you away. The quickening in this movie was an ugly blue lightening.  I'm too use to the lightning of the tv series to be ok with it.
